I'll contribute one point to this video, which was wonderfully done I might add. The war of attrition strategy was not to wear down the United States per-say until they couldn't fight any longer. Rather, the idea was to hold out until the presidential elections of 1864. This presidential election saw Abraham Lincoln running against former General George B. McClellan. McClellan was considered to be more sympathetic to the South and the Confederate hope, was that war weariness would make Abraham Lincoln unpopular enough that he would lose the election to McClellan who was then expected to sue for peace. The South would be able to negotiate their return to the Union from a favorable position that would allow them to ensure guarantees to their rights to own slaves in a reformed constitution. Their strategy was initially successful, as the Union lost most of its major engagements in the beginning of the war, and Abraham Lincoln seemed to be dropping in popularity along with general enthusiasm for the war. A few things changed that got his presidency back on the right track. Primarily, the appointment of Ulysses S. Grant to oversee military operations in Northern Virginia had one of the biggest impacts and Abraham Lincoln won reelection in a landslide, thus foiling the Southern strategy of attrition. The war ended within six months of the election.

Militarily, the South had no chance of winning. Zero. They were way too outmatched, and unlike the Revolution (where the colonies had an ocean separating them from Britain) railroads allowed the Union to easily move troops into rebel-held territory. However, wars are fundamentally about political objectives and not kill counts, so the South really had one prime directive: last until November 1864 and hope Lincoln was voted out of office. That actually came surprisingly close to happening--Grant's brutal attrition battles against Lee created an outcry in the North, and Lincoln spent most of 1864 convinced he would lose. If the South had done better at resisting Sherman, there would have been a horribly bloody stalemate with no end in sight, and I think Lincoln would indeed have been voted out and the South would have had a real shot at negotiated independence.

For the people who believe the war was not primarily about slavery:

While the war may have started because of the difference in economy, the sectionalism, and the fight for states’ rights, these issues were all rooted in slavery.

The difference in economy (agriculture and industry) was primarily because the North had free labor, and the South had slave labor (if the South were to lose their slaves, they would lose most of their workforce, which would severely damage their economy). The sectionalism at the time was primarily caused by the North developing without slavery (mostly because of the Northwest Ordinance), and the South developed with slavery. Lastly, the fight for states’ rights came from the South wanting the state govs to be able to decide whether slavery was legal or not.

John, I am an avid viewer, but must disagree on this episode. The escalation of both armed conflict and secession, surrounding the Nullification Crisis, forced the Compromise Tariff of 1833. This is the only reason why both full scale secession and armed conflict did not occur prior to 1860, though it was at "the tipping point." Between 1833 and 1860, protectionism reescalated, which in turn continued southern economic hardships under mercantilism. This was the sensitivity to Lincoln's election, of him not only being a "black republican," but also a very well known "Whig Republican." To omit this from your presentation, and only focusing on the immediate cause of slavery, is to do history no justice. It is the equivalent of stating a boat sank by a hole, but not by the turbulent waters that filled the boat.
It is very important to frame the issue of slavery appropriately. The 4 Declaration of Causes for Secession issued by Mississippi (and the like) clearly state that slave-state representation, in becoming a minority, was a direct threat to Southern economies. Which is congruent with the turbulence already caused by harsh protectionism and Northern majoritarianism. The South had been systematically plundered to subsidize Northern industries for the past 30 years, and though the South would unanimously vote against harsh tariffs -that deeply harmed Southern economies, the Northern Votes far outweighed a unified South. Essentially, the South was already backed into a economic "corner" by the time of Lincoln's nomination. The issue of slavery, in regards to secession, was the "back end of the wave," as a continuation of economic challenges to the South.
Moreover, there seems to be a common confusion of issues, between the reasons of secession and the reasons for the war. Both your episode and my argument above are concerned with the issues of secession, not the issues of the war itself. The two are disjointed. By the Montgomery Convention of Feb 1861, the Confederate States of America was a functional, sovereign government, that had already legally and peacefully seceded. It had an elected president, congressional body, constitution, a means to raise armed forces, and emissaries issued to Europe (the South's main trading partner).The Confederacy continued as a functional, sovereign country until 1865 (4 whole years), when the North forcefully removed its government after CFS armies surrendered. Instead of avoiding the bloodiest conflict in American history, Abraham Lincoln refused such things as peace brokering by Bonaparte the 3rd, for he claimed that the South had no right to secede (which it did), and invaded an established CFS on the grounds of both "retaliation" (post Fort Sumter incident provocations) and "reunification." Grant and Sherman were the Generals the North had needed, but refused to accept for so long.

Grant could lose a battle, and only fall back a few miles, knowing that the Southern forces against him could not fight another battle in short order, where he would recover.  Previous generals would often retreat all the way back to Washington when they were defeated, even if the they were threatening Richmond.  Grant wasn't a simple butcher, but was fighting the war on a strategic scale, when the Souths finest generals were expert tacticians, or operational commanders (fighting at the battle level, rather than the campaign.)  Grant's willingness to besiege Vicksburg in the West, and then in the East to push for constant attacks, and then a siege where he stretched the Southern forces thinner and thinner as he tried to cut off Richmond, show his overall strategy.

Sherman, on the other hand, took the idea of strategic warfare to a new and different conclusion.  He avoided almost every battle that could have slowed him down, instead destroying the Southern ability to maintain their armies, and crushing their morale (how would you react when you hear a large army has marched from Atlanta to Charleston, destroying everything of value, and no major Southern Army has even engaged him in battle on the way?)  Sherman also had been declared insane for saying early in the war it would take years and hundreds of thousands of men to defeat the South.
